stem: A ventilated patient has peak pressure 38 cm H2O and plateau pressure 20 cm H2O. What is the most likely cause of the elevated peak pressure?
rationale_correct: Large difference between peak and plateau indicates increased airway resistance.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct because resistance affects peak but not plateau. | B: Compliance problems raise both peak and plateau. | C: Overdistention raises plateau pressure. | D: Auto-PEEP raises baseline pressure, not just peak.
qa_summary: single best answer: yes; physiology accurate: yes; no repeat: yes

stem: A patient has peak pressure 34 cm H2O and plateau pressure 32 cm H2O on volume control ventilation. What does this indicate?
rationale_correct: Peak and plateau both elevated with small difference suggests poor compliance.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Values are elevated. | B: Resistance shows larger peak–plateau gap. | C: Correct because compliance issues elevate plateau. | D: Leak would reduce pressures.
qa_summary: single best answer: yes; physiology accurate: yes; no repeat: yes

stem: During spontaneous breathing trial, RR rises to 36/min and tidal volume falls to 250 mL in a 70 kg patient. What is the best interpretation?
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: RSBI >105 predicts failure. | B: Correct calculation. | C: High RSBI predicts failure, not success. | D: Oxygenation not primary issue here.
qa_summary: single best answer: yes; physiology accurate: yes; no repeat: yes

stem: On ventilator flow-time waveform, expiratory flow shows prolonged tail and does not return to baseline before next breath. What condition is most consistent?
rationale_correct: Incomplete exhalation indicates obstructive physiology with air trapping.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Restrictive lungs empty quickly. | B: Normal returns to zero baseline. | C: Correct because obstruction prolongs expiration. | D: Weakness reduces volume but not waveform pattern.
qa_summary: single best answer: yes; physiology accurate: yes; no repeat: yes

stem: Which finding best supports readiness for extubation?
rationale_correct: RSBI less than 105 suggests likely weaning success.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Acidotic hypercapnia suggests instability. | B: Correct predictive parameter. | C: High plateau suggests poor mechanics. | D: High FiO2 requirement suggests oxygenation instability.
qa_summary: single best answer: yes; physiology accurate: yes; no repeat: yes

sub_concept: Increased dead space from pulmonary embolism
stem: A ventilated patient develops sudden drop in ETCO2 from 38 to 22 mm Hg while PaCO2 increases from 40 to 55 mm Hg. What is the most likely cause?
rationale_correct: Divergence between PaCO2 and ETCO2 suggests increased dead space, as seen in pulmonary embolism.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Shunt affects oxygenation more than CO2 gradient. | B: Correct because dead space widens PaCO2–ETCO2 gradient. | C: Hypoventilation raises both ETCO2 and PaCO2. | D: FiO2 does not change ETCO2 directly.
qa_summary: single best answer: yes; physiology accurate: yes; no repeat: yes

stem: A patient on assist-control ventilation shows double triggering and patient discomfort. What is the most appropriate adjustment?
rationale_correct: Improper trigger sensitivity can cause dyssynchrony and double triggering.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Increasing VT risks lung injury. | B: Correct because trigger settings improve synchrony. | C: Oxygenation not primary issue. | D: PEEP reduction does not correct trigger issue.
exam_logic: Patient–ventilator synchrony improves comfort and ventilation.
qa_summary: single best answer: yes; physiology accurate: yes; no repeat: yes

stem: ABG shows pH 7.52, PaCO2 28 mm Hg, PaO2 95 mm Hg, HCO3 23 mEq/L. What is the primary disorder?
rationale_correct: Low PaCO2 with alkalemia indicates acute respiratory alkalosis.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct. | B: HCO3 not elevated significantly. | C: PaCO2 low not high. | D: Pattern does not show acidosis.
qa_summary: single best answer: yes; physiology accurate: yes; no repeat: yes

stem: A patient with ARDS has plateau pressure of 36 cm H2O. What is the best immediate adjustment?
rationale_correct: Plateau above 30 cm H2O increases risk of ventilator-induced lung injury. Tidal volume reduction lowers plateau.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Would increase plateau further. | B: Correct lung-protective strategy. | C: Rate affects CO2 more than plateau. | D: FiO2 does not change plateau directly.
common_trap: Chasing CO2 instead of protecting lung.
exam_logic: Keep plateau under 30 to protect lungs.
qa_summary: single best answer: yes; physiology accurate: yes; no repeat: yes

stem: A patient with Guillain-Barré syndrome has rising PaCO2 with normal lung compliance and clear chest imaging. What is the primary cause?
rationale_correct: Neuromuscular weakness impairs ventilation leading to CO2 retention without intrinsic lung disease.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Dead space not indicated. | B: Correct because muscle weakness reduces ventilation. | C: No imaging evidence. | D: Shunt primarily affects oxygenation.
common_trap: Looking for lung disease when mechanics are normal.
exam_logic: Weakness causes hypoventilation without compliance change.
qa_summary: single best answer: yes; physiology accurate: yes; no repeat: yes
